11AAA547B4614AF9B402FEE4C7025620.description: Research (e.g., in person interviews, written information, recorded or online interview) an Indigenous theatre artist and examine what impacts his or her work, considering questions such as What is the role of Indigenous theatre in the local community and society? Is it important to distinguish Indigenous theatre separately from non-Indigenous theatre? Does cultural identity influence the work?

CB9EE6AB0C0F4FD8AA472F38287FAB71.description: Conduct research on a contemporary First Nations, Inuit or Métis theatre company in Canada and report on such things as company philosophy or focus, subject or themes presented, discipline specific or interdisciplinary approaches and/or the potential influence of local cultural practices

91B689478B3A4851ADFE425DF5CF66F4.description: Discuss questions concerning the relationship between identity and art-making practices (e.g., Does culture influence the subject matter or themes of dramatic work? How might traditional practices inform the work of specific artists?).

5092876304DE4382AB5E6ED54CF4A2FF.description: Research contemporary and/or current theatre practices of First Nations, Inuit and Métis artists in Canada.

1283A5579A8D44C883B2BFD381FFAA47.description: Conduct an inquiry to examine Saskatchewan theatres and theatre artists (e.g., Gordon Tootoosis Nikaniwin Theatre, SUM Theatre, Persephone Theatre, Globe Theatre, Dancing Sky Theatre, Troupe du Jour, Curtain Razors, Listen to Dis, Deaf Crows, Live Five) whose work addresses local and/or global issues (e.g., food security, water access, health, migration, colonization, reconciliation, climate change, gender and sexual diversity, ethics and technologies, economic disparity, economic, social and environmental sustainability).

3D11743CE0584A77BEA1D5DAE9CFCEFC.description: Examine how theatre artists use their art form to question the status quo and empower others to influence change (e.g., challenging perspectives on gender equity).

DF159F3CD5164DAE9DDAFF6DBF9AD734.description: Practically explore a current social issue of interest (e.g., treaty education outcome TR12, indicator - analyze how the media currently depicts the treaty relationship and determine the effects this has on public perception, marginalized groups, issues identified in the media) and consider how one might respond through dramatic work.

9DAA2C07940C4AD8A33D4422AB012F5E.description: Analyze and practically explore a theatre movement that arose in response to social conditions (e.g., Paper Wheat in response to the creation of farming cooperatives in Saskatchewan, Native Earth Performing Arts in response to colonialism, Theatre of the Absurd in Europe and Butoh in Japan in response to WWII, Guerrilla Theatre in response to radical social movements of the 1960s, Bread and Puppets in the 1970s in response to social activism in USA).

8C70CD23F060475E9057F098C8C16272.description: Examine the role of the theatre and artists as potential agents of social change.

AFF3651C84044A90872B14D65B6867EC.description: Discuss the impact and contributions of contemporary theatre practitioners working within various theatre roles (e.g., writers, dramaturge, performers, directors, stage managers, designers of set/costume/lighting/sound, choreographers of fight/dance, music directors/musicians, technicians).

FDF6598648054BB5A9812B3E7CD5DF3B.description: Create a maquette or theatrical diagram of modern production choices for a play.

5BC8129BD94D4999AD7352C84FDD298E.description: Research and examine how past traditions inform contemporary theatre.

F16EC5C9842445B3872D50BB611D78F4.description: Recognize how artistic practices can be specific to a treaty territory, cultural and/or language group in Saskatchewan and Canada (e.g., examine drama and theatre traditions of newcomer students’ communities, treaty education outcome TPP12 - represent personal understanding of the concept, We Are All Treaty People).

49D5611754C849639644AF72B1DB1FB4.description: Discuss connections between Indigenous artistic traditions (e.g., song, dance, stories) and the land, identity and worldview.

CAAF160CBF7A4BD6BE30098C28C232F5.description: Research and experiment with contemporary theatre practices.

277048A221C4459896E701D2F0BECFD6.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

AA51057783E046C1A8BDDEBE53644D99.description: Pitch a proposal for a production, season or grant and defend the proposal to a panel of peers.

2721645D007C4D5692F492288669356B.description: Create a proposal, including sponsorship and funding plan (e.g., social media, PR and publicity, logo).

6AEBA31A521E4A50A6D8EFF2271E56E7.description: Develop an outline to describe an imagined theatre company (e.g., name, company members, season schedule, budget and location).

D7F2632F0F024803B881B5578FB19BDE.description: Create a vision and focus for an imagined theatre company.

D0973AFE75364216BCF37CA51C213BAC.description: Interview a member of a professional or community-based theatre company about their vision, focus and process (e.g., How do you determine your season? How do you promote your work? How do you get funding? How do you develop a budget? How do you recoup costs?).

31CD41BC7CB44B5BA90465C548A82280.description: Examine the purpose of theatre in societies.

AB2CCBE9459945B9B13C8CFE5E97FBAA.description: Discuss how viewing theatre shapes future decisions in making theatre

7BB03CEC824D4D75B63C42B4289A2327.description: Explore several different ways to critique (e.g., written, verbal, collage, multimedia, journal, monologue) using language specific to theatre or film.

C2C5BFF43045474291B8CF7F5416D53E.description: Recognize the effect the location of the theatre has on the audience, such as outdoor theatre, theatre in the round, site-specific theatre, historical theatres.

5EE36BBDD7EC4584AA944015A64A50AC.description: Reflect on the impact of directorial choices on an audience and one’s own experiences viewing plays.

673D7CC7172E49F4A8F12CEBB92DC50C.description: Discuss considerations a director makes when creating a film adaptation such as location, setting, directing the viewer’s focus through camera angles and shots, special effects, computer generated imagery (CGI) and editing.

926E59513CF54D43BF3280767466E078.description: View a filmed adaptation of a play and identify the qualities specific to film that cannot be replicated on stage and the qualities of staged performance that cannot be replicated through film.

600623DDD36F40B0A4DC36973B7470A0.description: Review and reflect on directorial choices in various genres of recorded and/or live theatre.

65A1F5FF0EEA48D9A29D4A47C12AAB50.description: Examine the differences and similarities between staged theatre and plays adapted to film.

9A31298902CD4B4FBDA0443070F13756.description: View and reflect on a live or recorded performance and discuss the role of the audience in various types of performances (e.g., conventional Western theatre, children’s theatre, forum theatre, site specific).

932DF499347C476889C808B125645E75.description: Respond critically, using appropriate theatrical language, to directorial choices in a variety of performance experiences (e.g., live, digital).

D447EDF6DA8B49519044BF781113FF61.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and international artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

5FF9B12687614C21AC52C5EF56B4F726.description: Reflect on problems, surprises or challenges that arose in the performance and how they might be resolved.

4EF5FA0FBFBE480398DF5FCC1295F5F7.description: Justify decisions made by various roles (e.g., director, actor, designer) to achieve intent.

29C02E202F7040DD86DD8654E32043ED.description: Demonstrate willingness to take creative risks.

BABCCDE77E5443FE97EB438AF9759F1D.description: Change the point of view of a scene or dramatic work by amplifying a technical or artistic aspect (e.g., incorporate contact improv, actor and audience interaction, replace the actor with an object or technical component, project digital images on moving actors, use social media conventions in performance).

B4A713094DCE475A94E9D6ACB5FA5086.description: Use a specific technical component (e.g., light, costume, sound, digital technologies) for symbolic purposes as a mode for communicating ideas.

D534B838116D4D99B6C43BC3BAE694E3.description: Reinterpret or imagine a scene or dramatic work through innovative use of various theatrical toolboxes (e.g., director, designer, actor).

FA1B0F865E82496C85D035AF2DB4DA64.description: Practically explore the director’s toolbox (e.g., communication of vision, interpretation of oral or written text, analysis and planning, creating a rehearsal plan) for artistic purpose.

E02790C39212443BB9FF3CEB3FC53A5E.description: Purposefully use the language of theatre in selected creative processes.

BA4AEAF8987945FFA4EE33CDC6B4998D.description: Present and sustain a performance for an audience (e.g., peers, invited guests, public) that demonstrates innovation (e.g., aesthetic and technical).

15F36BB2BF164D0EB0AD93E5F3909BD9.description: Engage, where possible, with Saskatchewan directors about their own creative processes (e.g., interview, research, email, view or listen online).

6F69AB105B994E4DB6BE95D879C8542D.description: Construct and revise the rehearsal process according to the style and needs of the production.

D6F9C33D77D04D8EBA1B10D4DE2E1488.description: Develop source material (e.g., analyze and/or decode text, image, sound, movement, research, story, idea) and build the drama work within the selected process.

F038A6E47B1343C0817B9849AADD8467.description: Work with peers to select a creative process and make a production plan (e.g., roles, budget, timelines, expectations).

B0095B9D536440F0A1E4BC8A86DBF222.description: Collaborate with peers, Elders or community experts to decide on the merits of various creative processes for building a specific drama work (e.g., play, collective creation, devised theatre, performance art).

E3B76FA7E0474610B7325CEFBEC7BE48.description: Demonstrate directorial choices for a performance that utilizes oral or written text and/or devised material.

BE57CC48DDFD41F4BE69B470C67C9AB7.description: Explore ways of expressing power, status and perspective through drama work (e.g., Image Theatre, Forum Theatre, contextual drama).

BCE8E59961984B3692B418CDBF4306F9.description: Analyze and describe how personal identity and cultural lens affects creation of the work.

594BECF9E33444C5BF8CBED366BAD837.description: When preparing a scene, monologue or play, consider questions such as: whose voice and perspective is being heard? Who is left out of the story? How does voice impact the story? How does the perspective impact the audience?

ED8CD49E7A8144F7AE5F2CF900C5BEC9.description: Assume roles in order to represent a variety of voices and perspectives.

CB3D2B1E27A74F968A188DC30FD91046.description: Express a multiplicity of voices and perspectives (e.g., self, family, community, marginalized individuals, silenced people in history, powerful figures, celebrities, extraterrestrials, fictional characters) through works of dramatic art.

D170CFEFDE8B4E31BDAE7293A90AB65B.description: Assess the strengths of the drama work and/or performance and reflect on the collaborative approaches, challenges, and individual contributions encountered in the creative process.

059E62D1F2B040F0B031D02BB0A48B55.description: Design the look and sound of a scene to reflect a genre or style (e.g., director’s notebook, sketches, production notes, maquette, set list).

8F97D71FDA304FD1898D74B27C353E04.description: Juxtapose unlike genre and style (e.g., use puppets to explore a political issue, create a Victorian ‘drawing room play’ using social media as script).

3AB8A516F6984046B9155ACD7EC26BBE.description: Select an aspect of theory and/or style and apply to own work through, for example: improvised play, performance art, monologue, scene and video

A5BF28E376A84C5A80557AA7F23BFCA4.description: Incorporate and justify the use of genre and style in own devised work.

B4C7D755B33F49C3B5411DC29F0A0638.description: Research style or genre and share learning (e.g., design a student-led workshop, act out a scene).

08D0FA1491E641C2B587580228E4CEA5.description: Create dramatic work demonstrating use of genre and style.

CAAADAB2AEE047819D733F869AED89F8.description: Devise and perform dramatic work inspired by world theatre traditions

DA80B6B1C0804F60906669F60B9BC374.description: Organize and document ideas for possible exploration (e.g., portfolio, journal, digital media)

9407D0C0FC18401E818ADF8F5FA7861E.description: Investigate how different styles have been applied to traditional plays (e.g., Macbeth adaptation to Pawâkan Macbeth).

C35FBFD0C2D84618BEC2B0ADC11CF608.description: Investigate how performance styles (e.g. mask, storytelling, shadow puppetry, naturalism, commedia) inform ideas.

095E19069C0C475EAC855F80BDB4AD6D.description: Use world theatre traditions to inspire ideas for own dramatic work.

B4C89258DB804A79903518D6F19A5204.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
